title: Direct sum
summary: The direct sum is an operation between structures in abstract algebra, a branch of mathematics.  It is defined differently, but analogously, for different kinds of structures. To see how the direct sum is used in abstract algebra, consider a more elementary kind of structure, the abelian group.  The direct sum of two abelian groups A {\displaystyle A} and B {\displaystyle B} is another abelian group A ⊕ B {\displaystyle A\oplus B} consisting of the ordered pairs ( a , b ) {\displaystyle (a,b)} where a ∈ A {\displaystyle a\in A} and b ∈ B {\displaystyle b\in B} . To add ordered pairs, we define the sum ( a , b ) + ( c , d ) {\displaystyle (a,b)+(c,d)} to be ( a + c , b + d ) {\displaystyle (a+c,b+d)} ; in other words addition is defined coordinate-wise. For example, the direct sum R ⊕ R {\displaystyle \mathbb {R} \oplus \mathbb {R} } , where R {\displaystyle \mathbb {R} } is real coordinate space, is the Cartesian plane, R 2 {\displaystyle \mathbb {R} ^{2}} . A similar process can be used to form the direct sum of two vector spaces or two modules.
